a friend of mine bought a wonderful Akasaka Nobuiye tsuba recently, very 
nice workmanship. Not all Nobuiye tsuba if not "the" Nobuiye should be 
disgarded to quickly.

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Matt,
> I haven't seen the guard in person, but here's something I wrote in 
> response to an off line question a couple of weeks ago.
>
> Jim
>   There were a number of makers working
>   in the Edo period that signed Nobuie, often including their place of
>   residence.  There are guards signed Kaga, Owari, Echizen, Akasaka, etc.
>   Nobuie.  Sometimes the work style of a particular later guard with 
> only a
>   two-character signature can be tied back to one of these.  I don't think
>   that I have ever seen a formal kanteisho written attributing a
>   two-character-signed guard to a specific regional Edo period maker, 
> though.
>   I have seen an NBTHK kanteisho written to "Nobuie (Edo period)" to 
> show that
>   it is not a forgery, but is one of the later makers.  I have seen 
> another
>   written to "betsujin Nobuie," meaning a different person, i.e., not the
>   famous maker(s).  I have also seen good quality, early Edo period tsuba
>   signed Nobuie fail shinsa as forgeries.
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
